description.narrative: Increasing Resilience to Climate Change in Coastal Areas and Community Settlements in Tuvalu.
Increasing Resilience of Coastal Areas and Community Settlements in Tuvalu to Climate Change NAPA 1
capital of a political entity

1. Number of islands in Tuvalu that have increased capacity to anticipate and address climate change-induced risks through targeted adaptation measures for costal protection, agricultural food security, and water management.
2. Extent on which the National Advisory Council on Climate Change (NCACC) is established (scale: 1. Inadequate; 2. Partial; 3. Largely)

comment.narrative: Operationally Closed

description.narrative: Increase the protection of livelihoods in coastal areas and island communities from dynamic risks related to climate change and climate variability in all inhabited islands of Tuvalu

N of government officers and planner Kaupule members and NGO personnel that have increased capacity in identifying climate risks planning adaptation measures and sustain community awareness on climate chnage issues

comment.narrative:
The countrys responses to climate change risks and adaptation are ad hoc and piecemeal and not adequately supported by legislation
Planners policy makers Kaupule and vulnerable communities are unable to anticipate climate change impacts and integrate these into policy revision financial planning and decisionmaking processes

At least 200 DoE and DoA officials and planners in other government agencies DoF Education DoH DMO PWD in Tuvalu and in the islands Kaupule and 30 personnel in NGOs participating in the project TANGO NCW are able to i identify climateinduced risks in coastal areas ii prioritize and plan effective adaptation measures on the basis of participatory assessments and iii sustain community awareness of climate changerelated risk issues

In JulyAugust 2014 a combined team from the Government including Agriculture Lands Public Works Education Solid Waste Agency of Tuvalu SWAT and nongovernment institutions including Tuvalu Association of NGOs TANGO Red Cross and Integrated Island Biodiversity IIB visited 4 schools Nauti Primary School Seventh Day Adventist Primary School Fetuvalu High School and Motufoua Form Seven Programme and the 8 island communities on the Capital Funafuti Nui Nanumaga Nanumea Niutao Vaitupu Nukulaelae and Nukufetau to disseminate climate risk information to school children and island communities During these visits a total of 578 people 306 males and 272 females received a training on climate risk information and its potential impact on food and water security and coastal erosion In addition 1733 school children also received similar information through presentations and quiz

description.narrative: Number of households in Tuvalu that have increased capacity to anticipate and address climate changeinduced risks through targeted adaptation measures

comment.narrative: Coastal communities face climate change risks largely due to lack of adaptive capacity
By the end of the project at least 1000 households in Tuvalu are able to anticipate climate changerelated risks and select the most effective risk reduction options

This target level was reported in the 2014 PIR as has been achieved through the delivery of awareness raising programmes to all island communities in the outer islands and on the capital reaching more than a 1000 households

description.narrative: Outcome 1 Enhanced capacity of public administration Island Kaupules communities and NGOs with policy support to plan for and respond to climate change risks in coastal areas and settlements
Existence of a functioning National Climate Change Advisory Council NCCAC

comment.narrative: There is no functioning national CC coordination mechanism in place
By the end of Year 2 the NCCAC is fully functional in coordinating climate change related policy and development processes
In January 2015 the National Advisory Council on Climate Change NACCC was established It was reported in the 2014 PIR The project is now actively involved in the NACCC

description.narrative: N of schools capacitated to conduct climatechange related education programmes

comment.narrative: Environmental issues are integrated into school curricula but very limited on climate change topics
By the end of the Project the 10 Primary Schools and 2 Secondary Schools functioning in Tuvalu are capacitated to conduct climate change related education programme

A Curriculum Development officer was funded by the NAPA 1 project to attend the Sandwatch workshop in New Caledonia in December 2014 The outcome of the workshop was a training workshop for teachers around the country in April 2015 The training was facilitated by the Curriculum Development Officer who attended the Sandwatch training The outcome of the training of teachers is the enhancement of teachers ability to teach climate change education programmers in their schools The next step is to incorporate Climate Change topics into school curricula both at primary and secondary school level

description.narrative: Number of coastal zone management related policy documents formulated and approved as a result of the project

comment.narrative: There is a lack of an integrated framework and human and institutional capacity for assessing planning for and addressing climate changeinduced risks at coastal areas or implementing integrated coastal zone management approaches at the national kaupule or community levels
By the end of the Project at least 2 National Policies or action plans on coastal management are developed or revised to integrate climate risks and resilience
A National Climate Change Policy Te Kaniva was endorsed in 2012 This policy was reported in the 2013 PIR

description.narrative: Outcome 2 Enhanced capacity of local communities to adapt to dynamic climaterelated threats through implementation of practical communitybased adaptation measures specifically tailored to each islands
Number of locally designed sustainable adaptation measures demonstrated in vulnerable coastal communities

comment.narrative: Disaster management efforts have increased preparedness for extreme events in some areas however there is a lack of planned measures and structured analysis of options to implement integrated coastal zone management and adapt to a broad range of both extreme events and gradual climate changeinduced hazards in coastal areas
By end of the project at least 2 communitybased adaptation measures employed by the project demonstrate their utility for coastal communities and provide lessons for replication

In December 2014 a team from the Department of Environment NAPA 1 and an independent EIA consultant visited Nukufetau and Nanumea to assess the likely impacts of coastal interventions on these islands Works are still continuing on the two islands and will be completed by March 2015

description.narrative: Outcome 3 Project knowledge and lessons learned are captured analysed and disseminated to facilitate replication of practical adaptation solutions in all islands
Availability of sectorspecific climate chnage information for projct stakeholders

comment.narrative: Currently there is no regular climate information made available for government planners and NGOs working in development and environmental projects
By the end of the Project the Government departments and NGO involved in the Project regularly received sector specific climate information to support planning and management processes

Currently there are no regular climate change information made available for government departments and NGOs However during the World Environment Day and World Biodiversity Day in June 2015 the project contributed to preparing climate change information for students at 2 Primary Schools and 1 Secondary School on Funafuti

description.narrative: Number of knowledge management products generated and disseminated

comment.narrative: Development projects currently do not systematically benefit from learning practices and project lessons on communitybased adaptation

Starting from Year 2 of the Project at least 5 lessons learned and best practises consolidated every year in form of case studies experience noted brochures photo stories or audiovisuals and disseminated directly to communities and national stakeholders

Since the last reporting period there has been very little incountry sharing of lessons learnt except in the form of handing out tshirts during the National Environment Week where tshirts giveaway bags and caps were distributed to school children youths and volunteers

description.narrative: Number of national regional or international events and platforms where project experience is presented

comment.narrative: Project related climate change information have been only shared during the PPG phase consultation meetings

Starting from Year 2 of the project at least 5 lessons learned and best practises consolidated every year in form of case studies experience noted brochures photos stories or audiovisuals and disseminated directly to communities and national stakeholders
In May 2015 the Interim Project Coordinator attended the Pacific Regional Climate Change Roundtable meeting in Samoa where lessons learned were shared with colleagues from around the Pacific region

description.narrative: Effective and responsive island-level governance to secure and diversify climate resilient marine-based coastal livelihoods and enhance climate hazard response capacity
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for women 15+ years old
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for men 15+ years old
total number of new full-time equivalent jobs created

Focus on “strengthening of community based conservation programmes on highly vulnerable near-shore marine ecosystems,” “adaptation to near-shore coastal ecosystem,” and “strengthening community disaster preparedness and response potential
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

I) # of early warning systems established and operational, II) # of 1 conveyance of inter-island transportation III) # of revised and updated island strategic management plans incorporating Climate Change Adaptation measures IV) # of published documents on traditional knowledge pertaining to marine resource management techniques V) # of trainings and trained national personnels on governance in the integration of climate risks into the community based management of marine zones (VI)Number of people/or islands benefiting from community managed areas (MMA's) that also supports marine based livelihoods
Resilience of island communities to climate change variability and risks is strengthened through participatory islandlevel planning budgeting and execution and communityled investments

Take up of climate resilient marinebased livelihood options
Percentage of the Tuvaluan population covered by the 247 early warning system
Outer island communities able to access climatedevelopment funds using climatemainstreamed ISPs

comment.narrative:
Traditional techniques that are resilient to changes in marine ecosystems have been lost or are not passed down by old people while access to new techniques materials and information from off island and overseas is poor These are limiting options for pursuing resilient appropriate and safe lowcost livelihoods
The existing communications systems are inadequate to send early warning message in a timely manner
No climate resilience investments made using the ISPs as a guiding tool

By the end of the Project at least 40 of the targeted households adopted at least one form of traditional resilient marine livelihood methods including canoe building traditional fishing methods postharvest fish processing or aquaculture genderdisaggregated data will be presented
95 of Tuvaluan receives early warning in a timely manner using one of the multiple communication lines genderdisaggregated data will be presented
By the end of the project at least eight adaptation priority actions one in each island at the island level outlined in ISPs are financed by either domestic or external resources and executed

This indicator has not been achieved
Onground activities on building resilience of marinebased livelihoods have not taken place Depending on the availability of a vessel traveling to outer islands it is expected that activities will start either in the last quarter of 2015 or first quarter of 2016
For work related to EWS preparatory work such as recruitment of a Telecommunication and EWS Expert has been done in order to expedite the procurement of all communications equipment to strengthen the existing communications systems
For islandlevel climate finance work this target will be completed once the CPEIR activity has been carried out and also ISPs have been revised to incorporate climate change actions

description.narrative: Capacity of outer islands enhanced to respond to increasingintensifying climate induced hydrometeorological risks
21 Relevant risk information disseminated to stakeholders AMAT 211

comment.narrative: The existing warningcommunication system with triplebackup system satellite phone landline and electricitypowered radio is inadequate to warn communities within a reasonable time due to deficiencies in power systems for telephone systems in the outer islands

By the end of the project at least 95 of populations are able to receive and respond to early warnings and take the appropriate actions following the warning genderdisaggregated data will be presented

Targets for this outcome have not been met However work in progress to recruit a Telecommunication and EWS Expert to help out with acquiring the costing for approved EWS communications equipment The consultant will be contracted through UNDP

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity of communities to access internalexternal financing for communitybased climate change adaptation through existing participatory development planning processes

31 Local development framework ie ISP_that integrate climate risks
32 Adaptation actions implemented from island level plans no and type AMAT 111

comment.narrative:
Only two islands have some reference to ISPs
Annual budgeting exercise has been undertaken only in one island
No adaptation action has been implemented based on Island Strategic Plans

By the end of the project all outer islands have their ISPs revised to integrate climate risks
Annual budgeting process building on the ISP is in place
By the end of the project at least eight adaptation priority actions one in each island at the island level outlined in ISPs are financed by either domestic or external resources and executed

In response to the 1st indicator Preparatory works has been done to collate relevant information from Kaupules the information includes annual budgets and ISPs As of now the IS Planning and Community Officers have collected all Island Strategic Plans except Nui and Vaitupus ISPs Nui and Vaitupu ISPs are yet to be endorsed by their Falekaupules These ISPs will be revised in detail by the responsible department Department of Rural Development with close consultation with Island Kaupules and Falekaupules Other useful preparatory works includes the creation of work profiles for Falekaupule and Kaupule members for ease references
In response to the 2nd indicator This objective will be fulfilled once the ISPs have been revised and adaptation actions included in ISPs
A KAP Knowledge Attitude and Practices household survey to target Funafuti and Outer Island Communities have started in June and the main objective is to assess the level of knowledge of island communities on various climate change topics to identify specific adaptation priority actions and draw up climate risks for each respective island in line with their ISPs

description.narrative: Marine based coastal livelihoods of Tuvaluan outer islands made resilient to declining productivity induced by climate variability and change

11 Households and communities have more secure access to livelihood assets disaggregated by gender AMAT 131
12 The area of Marine Protected Areas MPAs or Locally Managed Marine Areas LMMAs managed in a climateresilient manner
13 The level of awareness about links between improved marine ecosystem management and sustainability and resilience of subsistence marinebased livelihoods

comment.narrative:
Few households have access to traditional and resilient livelihood assets and methods Score2
Currently 76 km2 of island reef areas is under marine management includes Funafuti Conservation Area at 33km2 but currently no systematic management arrangement or resource monitoring framework is in place
Current understanding of the links between marine resource monitoring management and livelihoods is low

Score improved to 4 By the end of the project at least 50 of targeted outer islands households have access to climate resilient marinebased livelihood methods introducedstrengthened in the project genderdisaggregated data will be presented
The area of MPAMMAs is clarified and some form of management applied to at least a quarter of the reef area on each outer island area to be calculated with a corresponding climateresilient community management plan or Kaupule bylaw
Capacity to undertake creel surveys and maintain the database developed among communitybased MPAMMA management groups
At least 50 of Fisheries staff Kaupule women youth and fishers interviewed confirm a clear link between resource management and resilience of livelihoods genderdisaggregated data will be presented

In response to the 1st indicator This target has not been met as this is an ongoing activity at this moment There is an ongoing Knowledge Attitude and Practices KAP household survey activity disaggregated by gender that the project is implementing right now to assess and verify the amount of households and communities accessed climate resilient marinebased livelihoods
Score remains at 2 at this point in time
In response to the 2nd indicator There has been sharing of knowledge between PMU and Fiji Locally Managed Marine Area FLMMA 20 participants 3 from Tuvalu and the rest from Fiji with regards to the management of marine resources in Suva Fiji in May this year Lessons learned from this meeting were crucial as it helps the project plans smartly to engage communities to manage their marine resources in a climateresilient manner The outreach activity to the communities on the outer islands will be done in the third quarter depending on availability of vessels
In response to the 3rd indicator In April two workshops were conducted to increase awareness amongst responsible parties about the project and facilitate their active involvement Amongst the participants there were 22 men and 9 women
A Training of Facilitator activity was carried out in June and in this training participants were also taught about the importance of managing their marine resources sustainably for future generations Beneficial from this activity includes 34 men and 20 women and from these 54 participants one male participant is a person with disability

The purpose of this project is to reduce the impact of increasingly intensive wave activity through the compounding effects of sea-level rise and intensifying storm events, that is amplifying coastal erosion..

Strengthened adaptive capacity and reduced exposure to climate risks. Reduce the impact of increasingly intensive wave activity through the compounding effects of sea-level rise and intensifying storm events, that is simplifying coastal and erosion.
